======================================Sentinels of the Multiverse (Read on for the full review!)
======================================
TL;DRDon't let the fun and colorful graphics fool you, this comicbook-esque card game has a lot of depth and challenge to offer. It is well designed and fun to play, and also sports some great developers.(Note that there is no actual story or campaign mode. You set up a battle and get to the action.)

======================================
Pros+ Graphics: Colorful comicbook style!
+ UI: Immersive and in-line with the comic-book theme. Looks really cool. Some things could be bigger or smaller, I feel.
+ Sound: Good music, satisfying sound when cards are moved.
+ Variety: Heroes and villains all have a unique style and playstyle.
+ Simple: To play, hard to master. There is a lot of depth to hero and card interaction.
+ Convenient: Put away your rulebooks and damage counters!
+ Pre-built: No deckbuilding meta stress. Pick up and play. Also, this is probably a big factor in how balanced this game is.
+ Faithful: More video game adaptions should be this smooth.
+ Developers: Communicative, engages with community regularly.
+ Multiplayer: The developers promised it. The developers delivered. No matter what the game, the ability to play with friends is always a plus!
+ Price Point(DLC): You can pickup the season pass and (in the future) the second season pass for tons of DLC/content, however...

Cons- Longevity: Base game content is sprase without the DLC, although keep in mind it's not about the amount of vilains, but the way the fights go down, that add to the longevity.
- Campaign: If you are the type who likes to unravel story, conquer enemies and levels, upgrading and powering up and unlocking achievements and abilities and cosmetics along the way...this won't be for you.
- UI: Interaction at times can be stiff or finnicky.
- Story: Would be nice if the starting dialogue was tailored based on villain, heroes present, and environment. For example, maybe rivals skip the small talk and just diss each other.
- Confirmation: For example, with multiple card discards, it seems odd to go one at a time with confirmation, instead of batch selecting with a highlight and then confirming.

Neutral+/- You will probably have to do a little research to learn to play well early on. Stick to low difficulty stuff until you learn your interactions.

======================================
IntroductionSentinels of the Multiverse is an adaption of a physical board/card game. It offers an accessible, challenging, and varied experience to anyone willing to put in a little time to learn the intricacies. It is a faithful reproduction, balanced, satisfying, and the developers seem solid with a lot of community interaction and involvement. The comic styled theme is deftly executed, which adds a lot to the experience and charm of this title.

GameplayYour gameplay will consist mostly of strategizing: you pick what heroes to use, villain to face, and environment to do so in; by carefully choosing what cards to play, what cards to use, and the order certain events happen in, you can have a large degree of impact on how well or poorly you perform in your fights against evil. The tutorial covers the basics and is comprehensive, but can leave you lost as to how you are supposed to properly utilize heroes, or what heroes may be good for specific tasks. My advice in this regard is that no matter how you approach this game, if you are new to it, stick with the same heroes and an easy villian initially, and you'll learn soon enough.

The expansions massively increase the size of the roster, but even with the base game, there is a large variety of options for villains and heroes of which all feel unique; offering you the ability to adapt or to play the way you want with a large degree of freedom. While certain heroes are definitely more suited to certain villains, you don't ultimately have to use them to be successful.

In Sentinals of the Multiverse, you put a card into play at the start of your turn; this card may be a one off, a piece of equipment that stays on the field, or an on-going effect/power that can be utilized every turn. After you play a card, you can use one of many powers, of which each hero has a unique variety, as well as their own inbuilt power. Normally, you can use one power per turn; these powers can be anything from drawing one or two cards, healing your team, damaging the enemy or yourself, dealing low damage to many (or all) targets, or buffing your fellow teammates. Equipment and powers tend to fuel your cards--in turn fueling your hero--and be where most heroes derive the bulk of their strength or utility. After you have run out of powers you can use, you will draw a card, and then your turn will end. Pretty simple, right? It's really the interactions that make up the intracacy of this game, which is beautiful, because the actual act of playing is simple and easy, but the ability to do so well is entirely about your knowledge and cunning. This makes for satisfying defeats and triumphs.

GraphicsThe art could certainly be better in some respects, but the style is consistent and very well executed. There could stand to be more animations and effects. The comic style lends itself to nice and quick transitions and creative menu graphics. Everything is bright, colorful, and vivid, so you really get that saturday morning hero vibe at all times.

Well, being that this isn't exactly a AAA 3D game, I can't comment on lighting, shaders, the quality of the models and animations, etc. so that's about all you'd want to keep in mind.

AudioThe music in SotM is very pleasing. I almost don't want to start games because I really like the main menu track especially. The sounds utilized for the various damage type are actually quite fitting and have their own charm. I really like the sound of the cards. Sound seems underutilized in SotM, and I feel like it could desperately use some subtle sounds when highlighting menu options and especially when clicking them. Well, the good news is, you don't really need much sound in a title like this, so it doesn't have as much impact as it would in a 3D adventure FPS.

ConclusionSentinels of the Multiverse is a great card game for those familiar or unfamiliar with the physical game. It offers a lot of pros, with almost no significant cons. It's easy to pick up, but it might take you a bit to learn how to utilize heroes to their fullest. The graphics and music will keep you pleased while you are sitting there trying to think your way through anything, or waiting on a friend in the newly implemented multiplayer.

If you are a fan: Pick it up.
If you are new: Consider picking it up. Definitely pick it up if there's a good sale.
If you are new but love the genre: Pick it up, you'll be pleased, but plan to get the DLC.
If you are new and willing to pay a bit for the DLC: DEFINITELY pick it up, the expansions massively increase the available content.

reviewText:
Digital version of an incredibly addicting tabletop game with tons of replay value. The UI is smooth and easy to use, and all the cards are very readable at different resolutions. The ability to active/use cards without having to double-click each one is very handy once you get used to the game and learn the cards by heart - which will happen if you use a hero long enough. The music is great as well, which was a pleasant surprise, and fits the superhero theme wonderfully. The inclusion of unlockable variant promo cards is a great addition, because each varant changes up the base power of the hero, or in the villain's case can really change the way the villain plays. This adds even more variety and combinations to a game already full of hundreds of hero/villain/environment combinations. And with the expansions inevitably on their way, there'll be even more. The tutorial is also really well done so you don't have to worry about being familiar with the tabletop rules before hand. It really walked through everything you could possibly need to know about how the game works, which is nice for those who've never played before.

On the flipside, the only thing I don't really like about this digital version is the lack of online multiplayer, although it is coming in a future update. The game does, however, lend itself really well to playing multiplayer locally by simply sharing the computer. And of course being able to play the game solo when you're craving a Sentinels fix is really where this game shines. Controller support would also be nice for playing on a TV, but that is also coming down the pipe eventually. Handleabra games is really doing a nice job of making the transition from physical boardgame to digital version.

As for the gameplay itself, it plays exactly like the tabletop version. Each player takes control of a superhero and teams up to take down a villain. Each hero has it's own unique deck of cards with wildly varying playstyles between each hero. Legacy, for example, is the paragon of justice who uses his cards and abilities to buff and defend his team of heroes, while someone like Tachyon uses her super-speed to burn through her deck drawing and discarding cards, many of which do more damage based on how many specific cards are in her discard pile. Each hero's deck of cards fits the hero's theme and superpower wonderfully, making for a different experience and strategy with each hero.

However, the villains also have a deck of cards full of minions and nasty super-powered attacks to take down the heroes. At some point during the game the villain's card will trigger an effect that causes it to flip over, which changes up the mechanics of how the villain plays - and sometimes changes the max HP the villain has. Plus each villain has a nemesis (or multiple ones) attached to it, which means the villain does extra damage to his nemesis, and vice-versa. And you can't forget about the environment you're playing on. After the villain has had his turn and all the heroes have gone, the environment itself gets a turn and draws a card from it's deck. Sometimes the environment deck helps the heroes out in someway, most of the time it does horrible, horrible things to the players like having pterodactyls steal all of your equipment. Each enviroment has it's own gimmicks to it's deck. Megalopolis has lots of city hazards like a speeding train that can damage both heroes and villains, or cops that show up to aid the heroes. Meanwhile something like Wagner Mars Base has a self-destruct timer, which if it reaches the end kills both the heroes and the villain and everyone on the Mars base ending in a draw.

The game has hundreds of combinations, as each time you play you pick a villain, and environment, and anywhere between 3-5 heroes. Everytime you play even just changing one of those from the previous game can really affect the outcome of the game and change the strategy you'll be using. The game has so much variety, and the rules are so simple to pick it up, that it makes itself very addicting. You can play dozens of times and still be surprised when something crazy happens that flips the current game on it's head. I really can't recommend this enough.

reviewText:
It's a good adaptation of the card game: a cooperative superhero game.

Each player has one or more heroes, and there's one villain and one environment. Each of these has its own deck, so there's a strong theme for each. Eg. Ra is a straightforward hero who burns things, gets certain cards into play, then helps everyone burn everything. Legacy mostly buffs other characters, Tempest is good at crowd control, and so on. No character is totally locked into one role, though. The villains and environment play automatically (play top card of deck, follow rules on villain card) and each has its own theme. The villains have two modes with special conditions for flipping, so each battle has distinct phases like Baron Blade giving up on his superweapon to attack you directly. You're racing to get hero cards into play while fighting the villain and his minions and averting some location-based disasters like angry T-rexes or a Martian self-destruct device. So, there's a constant struggle to cope with threats as they arise and there are tough decisions to make about what to focus on. Expect to lose sometimes, especially against the nastier villains and environments. reviewText:
OverviewSentinels of the Multiverse is a super hero themed single player/cooperative card game that offers a unique twist on the genre by having you manage a team of heroes with unique abilities instead of playing units to fight your opponent. Unlike most card games, all cards are available from the start--you don't have to unlock anything. There is a physical version of the game, and this digital version is perfectly accurate to the physical one.


GameplayPeople familiar with card games similar to Magic will find some very basic similarities in this game, but for the most part, Sentinels is fairly unique. Rather than pitting you against another player, you (and up to 4 other people) choose 3 to 5 hero decks and are tasked with playing against a villain deck that runs itself while dealing with the hazards posed by an environment deck. Unlike Magic and its derivatives, instead of fighting with creatures or units, your team of heroes relies entirely on their innate abilities and the various passive, active, and one-shot abilities represented by their cards to defeat their opponents.

Sentinels offers a fresh, interesting take on the card game genre and pulls it off very well. Every villain poses a fun, unique challenge and every hero has its own, interesting way of taking on those challenges and synergizing with other heroes. Even the locales in which you play bring their own unique flavor to the game and shake up the way you approach your goal. Sentinels is a lot more about the rules set by each specific villain and location than it is about its basic rules, which means gameplay varies more than in other card games from match to match.

Its cooperative gameplay also sets Sentinels apart from other card games, and makes it one of the few options out there for people who like card games but aren't interested in a competitive experience.

VisualsThough the art on some of the older cards may be a bit simplistic, which actually made me overlook the game at first, the art on newer cards has improved a lot. Overall, Sentinels has a very charming art style appropriate to its comic book theme.


Replay ValueWith so many combinations of heroes, villains, and evironments--along with advanced difficulty mode and monthly challenges published by the developers--Sentinels offers a LOT of replayability.


ConclusionSimply put, Sentinels is a lot of fun to play. For TCG/CCG veterans, it's a unique, refreshing take on a familiar and somewhat stagnant genre; for players new to the genre, it's an accessible card game that's fun and easy to learn yet offers plenty of depth to hold their interest. The art may not be as breathtaking as what you'd find on most popular card games, but this is a book you definitely don't want to judge by its cover.

reviewText: This is a board / card game that you either love or really dislike. I'm in the first team, and I find this to be an excellent version of the game!

Amazing! Absolutely amazing!

I love card strategy games and Sentinels of the Multiverse is no exception. The world of Sentinels that is brought to us through the games wonderfully expresses the creators' love for their favorite comic book settings while at the same time offering interesting characters and stories that are all their own.

The game holds great depth and variability between the multiple heroes, villains and environments which can comprise a game: each of them is well designed, both mechanically and thematically, to the point where I have a blast playing as any heroes in any environment against any villain. Comboes and synchronicity are everywhere: two heroes you may not like individually may have a combo together that you love, or a villain that you trounced easily in the city might be a completely different challenge when facing her in the ruins of Atlantis. It is an adventure just to explore the full space of possibilities which the game holds.

I'd say the Steam version of the game is well worth it, even if you are planning on acquiring (or already own) the tabletop version: the Steam version lets you get in some intensive play in which you control the entire team of heroes and have the opportunity to experiment with extreme plays and risky, involved combos before suggesting them at the game table. Better to try it out in this setting, where the computer keeps track of all those stacking effects and lets you trace back (in a limited capacity) through a sequence of plays back to a precise phase you want to re-examine or retry.

I was disappointed at first that the Steam version doesn't have multiplayer, but I am sure that it is in our future.

Sentinels of the Multiverse is a fully co-operative card game with a heavy comic book theme. You pick a villain, a group of heroes, and an environment to battle in, and then fight it out. The game plays mechanically simply... each hero gets to play a card, use a power, then draw a card... But there is a lot of depth and complexity here, and you'll need to come up with clever strategies to keep ahead of the game.

Variety and replayability are key here, and that's expressed well in the cards. Picking a character doesn't just change a couple of variables; everyone has their own completely unique deck with their own gimmicks that come in to play. Bunker is a guy in a transforming mech suit, with different modes that improve some of his traits at the cost of others. Tachyon is a speedster who blasts through her deck, being able to launch absurdly powerful attacks the bigger her discard pile is. The Visionary is a precognitive psychic who specialises is controlling the flow of the game over direct damage, and so on. Unlockable variants take this a step further, giving characters alternate base powers that can substantially change how they play.

As someone who's a big fan of the physical card game, this is my preferred way to play; there can be a lot to keep track of and it's great to have the game do this for you, especially with any special information only a click away. They've also added weekly challenges to take on, Steam achievements, and a lot of other additional elements.

Basically, if you have any love for these types of games, you can't afford to pass Sentinels by. I recommend not just getting this game, but also the DLC season pass; the amount of extra content already out is *absurd*, with new heroes, environments, and villains, and more on the way, and the game gets exponentially better as you can try out new combinations. For the price, the DLC is a steal.

Also, the music kicks ♥♥♥.

The tabletop version of Sentinels of the Multiverse is a cooperative puzzle/risk-management game in which each player takes the role of a single Hero with a customized deck. The players then work together to cover each others' weaknesses and bring down the Villain. A third type of deck, Environment, defines the place the fight is taking place and adds complications.

In the video game version, a single player takes control of the entire heroic team, unless you're using online multiplayer. Bizarrely, it's actually easier this way; the single player has more to keep track of, but can manage all the heroes as a unit. It makes it MUCH easier to pull shenanigans, like making sure multiple heroes keep their pieces of a card combo ready for use or having one entire hero present for the sole purpose of dying (poor Tempest ...)

Overall this is a fun card battler, with a lot of potential for growth. It should be noted, though, that it's seriously on the easy side for a cooperative game. While something like five out of six games of Knizia's Lord of the Rings or two out of three games of Elder Sign end in failure, I've only ever lost against Sentinels of the Multiverse when playing carelessly or going for a stunt" victory for an achievement. Using three-hero teams and avoiding using more than one of the most powerful heroes (Legacy

Sentinels of the Multiverse is a faithful adaptation of the excellent card game of the same name- the rules are excatly the same as the card game, meaning if you're already familiar with the tabletop game, you can easily jump in and start playing right away. With the exception of the first three mini-expansions, there is only the base game at the time of writing, but more expansions are supposed to be out soon.

However, the PC version of the game does have one major flaw; that being that it's essentially just a direct port of the tablet version of the game- nowhere does it try to update the controls or interface to take advantage of the wider variety of controls you can use on a PC. You use your mouse in place of your finger, and that's about the only real change- a real pity, especially when you consider that they're selling the PC version for 5 USD MORE than the tablet version, so doesn't that warrant some extra development time to take advantage of the extra features a PC can give us?

Despite this, Sentinels is still the same light strategy co-op card game that tabletop fans will expect. Three to five heroes take on a villain deck, each with their own unique strengths and weaknesses. Unlike games such as Magic the Gathering or Yu-Gi-Oh! where you construct a deck before the game, all the decks in Sentinels of the Multiverse is fixed, allowing each deck to have a different feel and playstyle to better suit the feel of the character. For example, if you're playing as the heroic Legacy, you'll find plenty cards that allow you to support other heroes, increasing their damage output, or even protecting them from damage. If you play as the super speedster Tachyon, you'll constantly be playing multiple cards and building up for a final strike. If you play as the psychic Visionary, you won't be doing much in terms of direct damage, but you'll constantly be manipulating decks, allowing you to pick which cards will be drawn next. And this doesn't just apply to the heroes- the villains and environemnts are equally varied in that each feels significantly different from the others, despite all working under the same rules.

Having played the game dozens of times in real life, I'm glad to be able to play this on my computer now (shuffling all those decks for a solo game makes setup a bit of a pain), and I'm eager to see the rest of the expansions make it in- I can't wait to play as Omnitron-X and The Scholar, or to battle against Iron Legacy and The Ennead.

So far I give SotM a 7/10. When/if they add in multiplayer/campaign, then this will rise to an 8/10.

reviewText:
Sentinels of the Multiverse is a computer card game. In it, you control a group of heroes, and you combat a villain. The game is represented by cards – each character is a card, with their own power and hit points, and their own unique deck. The game proceeds by having the villain (controlled by an AI) play, then the heroes play, with each hero having their own hand of cards, and then having the environment (again controlled by an AI) play.

The gameplay is about what you’d expect out of something like this, and all in all, the decks of the various characters are reasonably interesting. The villain throws something at the heroes every turn, be it some sort of attack, a minion, something which blocks their progress, ect. Sometimes, the villain card itself will attack as well on top of whatever the card they drew doing.

Likewise, each of the player characters in their own turn gets to play a card, then use a power, and finally draw a card. This power can either be the power on their card, or a power on a card they played. Some cards give passive bonuses, some are powers which have to be activated during the power turn, and some just are a one-shot ability which does something.

The environment basically does stuff to help or impair the heroes and villains. Some of the cards are really disadvantageous for the heroes, some hurt the villains, some do very little, some are easily gotten rid of, and some are very deadly.

While all of this is reasonable enough, it becomes clear very quickly that the game is short on content. The game comes with ten heroes, four villains, and four environments. Given you can play with up to 5 heroes every round, you’re really looking at only a handful of games before you run out of new content. There is an “advanced” mode for the villains, but it is really ultimately just a minor tweak which ups the villains’ difficulty rather than giving a real burst of new content.

But there are packs of heroes and villains which can be purchased as DLC…

And that’s really what this is – the base game is basically a demo for the “full game”. You can buy the season 1 DLC pack for as much as the base price of the game ($20 right now) which greatly increases the content – overall adding 8 new heroes, 14 new villains, and 8 new environments. The base game experience just isn’t very varied, and you will likely quickly become bored with fighting the villains after one or two times.

There isn’t really a story or anything else – while there are character background pages, expecting any story beyond that will leave you disappointed. And while there is a new weekly challenge every week, most of them require the DLC, and in any case, they’re just the standard scenarios, just with preset villains and hero sets – and as far as I can tell, none of them really incorporate stories or anything special like that.

Really, then, this isn’t a complete game without the DLC – so expect to spend as much as the base game + the DLC, meaning this is basically a $40 game, not $20. At the sort of price range they’re asking for, I don’t think this game is really worth it – frankly, I got about three hours of vague interest out of it, followed by about five hours of achievement hunting and the realization that I wasn’t really having fun anymore.

Overall, I don’t think that spending the extra money is really going to make it all that much more fun – just increase the amount of time you spend on it being vaguely amused at best. There are just so many more games out there which try so much more to make you happy, I just can’t really say that you’d be justified spending your time on this one. It isn’t awful, and it is an okay-designed card game, but there’s just nothing special about it.

Board game come video game with card battling superheroes and villains.

----

+ Hero deck designs are interesting

----

I've never played or heard of the associated board game, but I can compare it to other card battling video games without too much bias. To that end - this sucks.

I'll break it down with some choice arguments;
- The game begins with a tutorial that basically plays the game for you for 15 minutes whilst explaining very little in a lot of words.
- The meat of the gameplay involves playing various combinations of heroes on a choice of stages against a choice of villains with no overarching purpose or story to speak of at all.
- You cannot customise any of the decks in any way.
- The interface is clunky to use and confusing to look at.
- The pace of the game is monumentally slow, particularly if you have to read a lot of card text (which you most definitely will).
- A lot of the game is locked behind the DLC paywall, which to my mind is priced quite high considering most of it just adds more heroes, villains and stages to choose from and does nothing for the directionless gameplay.
- As of this writing, there is basically no online community to speak of.

It's not all doom and gloom though, the decks that are in play are quite interesting and each hero has a unique theme, feel and playstyle. The villains do pose quite a threat and the addition of the environment having a deck is interesting, although it often seems to screw you in seemingly unfair ways. I expect these aspects probably make for a great board game, so it's a shame that as a functional video game this is kind of a failure.

Overall? There are a lot of vastly superior options if you want to play a card game. The only reason I can think of to get this is if you really enjoy the board game, but even then - just play the board game. Then you can threaten your friends with physical violence and liven the whole thing up a bit.

reviewText:
Alright, so it's time I wrote an actual review for this game.

How do I begin? I recieved this game through Humble Bundle and was quite excited to try it. From the first moment opening the game, I am flooded with many bright colors - not a bad thing in its own right. Immediately, it seems as though much of the artwork looks much worse up close than I had imagined. I can overlook artistic simplicity and the most basic of character design if the gameplay makes up for it. After all, nice artwork is really just a bonus in a really solid card game.

So let's talk about gameplayThe short answer: it's a mess.
The long answer: after playing several games, let me say that the gameplay feels whelmingly complicated because you are in control of very little within the game. You will draw a lot of cards, you will discard a lot of cards. The cards you actually manage to play will slowly whittle down the villian's health. As the player, you manage 3-5 heroes that each has their own deck and trash pile, as well as a playing field. There is a predefined turn order starting with the villain, moving to your heroes, and ending with the environment. Your freshly baked cookie cutter heroes have enough variety to their cards at least, just enough to spend a stupid amount of time looking through awfully designed cards.

So gameplay is rather unbalanced, but these qualities do not make an awful game, just an underdeveloped one.

Unforgivable FlawsThe first unforgivable flaw to this game is the DLC. There is several times the content of the game contained in the DLC. Copying the brilliant concept from the massive game failure Evolve, there will also be multiple DLC season passes. On top of that, the first season pass alone is twice the price of the game. So apparently, it was cheaper to build the entire game engine and starting content than some extra characters and environments.

The second unforgivable flaw is the UI. Oh god the UI. Someone needs to set these developers down in a room and explain what a readable text and stylized text are because they don't understand what either are. The player is constantly baraged with all sorts of difficult to read text that doesn't look suited to a comic book or easy to understand. The cards are a mess of difficult to read text that I often find myself reading multiple times to figure out what in the world I'm reading. Scaling of cards is another problem. Do to the nature of the text embedded on the cards, scaling them down looks horrendus. The UI also includes an order system that is brought up every time a group takes damage. This is fine when I need to select 2 of however many cards I want to deal damage to, but what about when there is only one, or when the whole group takes damage with no side effects? Cards also fly by giving just enough time to read them that it is frustrating when they suddenly disappear. On top of all this, the abbundance gradients and clashing colors don't exactly make me feel any better.

The third unforgivable flaw is the completely undelivered aspects of what it promises.
Beautifully rendered backdrops? Wait, the tiny, jagged, N64 level 3D landscapes? That is not a selling point.
Brand new artwork for each hero and villain? Well it may be new, but a couple of static images isn't exactly a selling point either. I have also failed to mention how the low quality characters become multiple times worse in the card images.
The music leaves much to be desired, but I could overlook it. Though I will not overlook the music in aspect to the DLC. There are currently 4 volumes of soundtracks. Divided into the sets of DLC. Yet another shameful display of money grabbing.
The unlockable variants in game through secret challenges are no joke. They are so secret, I can't find them in any menu leaving me only to assume they have arbitrary unlock systems.
In SummarySentinels of the Multiverse is a game with some potential. The comic book-esque style it advertised is horribly lacking. The UI is horrendous, the artwork is amatuer, and the music in not any better. If you can get past these flaws, all you have to look forward to is an unbalanced, shallow card game full of cookie cutter characters.

As a fan of both collectible trading card games and superheroes, Sentinels of the Multiverse hits a special sweet spot for me.

The graphics are colorful and pretty. The style is authentically superhero in nature, feeling like panels lifted from a comic book. I appreciate the page turn wipe mechanic to illustrate the rotation of turns from character to character; though, this effect slows the game down, so I eventually did turn it off. Also, the animations for damage infliction have been improved since launch, which demonstrates the developers dedication to refining and expanding the game, though these quickly become tedious.

The characters are diverse, as are the cards that you play to simulate their superpowers and manuevers on the battlefield. In general, the cards are well-illustrated and have great flavor text. Combining the abilities of different heroes often results in synergies that mirror a team of superpowered beings working together to defeat one arch-villain, as well as containing that random element that can make CCGs addicting by their ability to reveal combinations and pitfalls over time.

I did find the characters to be wildly out of balance, with some being useful against virtually every foe and in every circumstance. While other characters require very particular draws or circumstances, or the understanding and exploitation of a self-damage mechanic to make them effective. I tended to avoid these, focusing instead on looking at the pool of abilities that the team possessed, which may well have been the focus the developers had in mind.

Similarly, most of the villains are interesting puzzles to solve that present different challenges depending on your chosen cast of characters and the environment in which you do battle. However, some villains operate under a broad rule-breaking mechanic that renders a particular character almost useless, or they have one particular trick around which you have to orient and time your strategy. I felt those villains had less replay value than the more broadly accessible and understandable villains. Others may appreciate these asymmetric enemies more than I do.

Fortunately, the season pass has, thus far, yielded fun additions of heroes, arch-villains and environments. If I had a criticism, I'd like to see more playable hero characters in relation to the number of arch-villains, but the mix might be sweeter to someone else's taste.

The music is upbeat from the main screen and varies appropriately with the various environments; though, like the comic book page turn wipes, I did eventually turn it off. Much more quickly, I turned off the sound effects: those become repetitive almost immediately (especially the projectile damage sound effect, which gets played frequently).

A major shortfall of the game is the lack of customization of individual hero decks. While variants on the various heroes and villains in the game can be opened up by meeting very specific gameplay requirements, they amount to having a single different core power. Being able to unlock and select different cards in an attempt to kit out a particular hero to face a specific enemy would have added another layer of strategic depth and might have made the more narrow villains more interesting to me.

Taking into account the fast game play, the colorful illustrations, the great writing on the color text and myriad combinations of heroes, arch-villains and environment (with many more coming down the pipe) that play out in many different ways, I can't help but to give this game a total thumbs-up.

Sentinels of the Multiverse is a computer adaptation of the tabletop card game of the same name. It is very faithful to the original and really captures the essence and feel of fielding a team of superheroes against a villain (and their minions) in a unique environment. One of reasons that I enjoy the game is that it does a good job of keeping track of all of the on-going abilities, pluses, minuses, impacts and conditions which are easy to forget or overlook when playing the card game. I *believe* that there are a few minor bugs in logic to still hammer out, but for the most part I think that the game is very enjoyable.

There are also Variants of the heroes and villains, so you have some desire to go back and keep playing in order to unlock another aspect of your favorites. If you prefer Handalabra gives you a code when you click on More Info, so you can simply unlock the varients quickly and easily.

This is a terrific game to get a quick skirmish in. These battles last 30 minutes or so, so they are not too long. I found the music compelling and sometimes find myself humming the theme. I wish there was a little more variety in the sound effects. All melee attacks sound the same; all projectile attacks sound the same, etc. It would be very cool if Expatriette’s Tactical shotgun sounded differently than Wraith’s Throwing Knives. For better or worse there is no character speech at all in the game.

The artwork on the cards is good, effective for the style. I enjoy it, although some may find it underwhelming. I also laugh at the subtle humor in their characters.

I find myself really looking forward to the next DLC to add to the list of villains and environments. As of this writing Multiplayers is approaching testing, but I saw people enjoying it at Gen Con.

If you enjoy Superheroes, or non-stress card games, this game is a sure hit.

The graphics are limited to drawing of the various heroes and villians, with some slight changes as they take damage and become incapacitated, as well as damage animations. The music however is pretty badass. But what about the gameplay?

The tutorial is recommended when you start to get the basics down; the villian has a turn where they play cards, and then the heroes go. Each hero can play a card, use a special power, and then draw a card. Certain things may cause you to skip one or more phases, and if you skip the first two on your own you draw two cards. After all the heroes go, the environment you are on has a turn, and this can be good or bad depending on what environment you pick.

The goal is to defeat the villian, but each one is different, and this is where the meat of the game comes in; the strategy. A fight against the same villian can be different depending on which environment you have; you can also have your team  be anywhere from 3 heroes up to 5, which can cause differences in the battle as well, and each heros deck and powers make them distinct from one another. Also, each villian also has an advanced mode if you're looking for a more sizeable challenge. So the number of various scenarios you can have is very large.

The game has no story or campaign of the sort at the moment of this writing. They have introduced what is called a 'weekly one shot' where the community gets a specific challenge based on a certain group of heroes versus a certain villian in a certain environment, and then are encouraged to discuss it on the forums. Where it isn't original, it offers variant versions of certain character decks. The UI is helpful, colorful. and loyal to the original game's art. Again, where it isn't totally faithful to the art, it adds more by depicting characters at different amounts of damage.

For people who own the card game, this will really let you explore the game fully, because the computer takes away all the fiddly counters. Less time spent with setup, and book keeping, means more time spent playing. Due to this, I have gained a better understanding of the game, and enjoy it more.

You should know this: The various combinations of heroes, environments, and villains can make the game nearly impossible to win, or ridiculously easy to win. Experience with the various decks will eventually guide you to the difficulty that you would like.

On that note, Sentinels currently provides weekly scenarios for you to beat. It's nothing more than different combinations of decks, but like I said, that's what makes the game challenging.

reviewText: This is a great way to play Sentinels of the Multiverse. The app takes care of all the math. You just draw and play cards. I like that you can play this solo or with friends online. The one shot challenges are a fun and neat addition that the card game doesn't have.

Firstly, I really like cooperative games, so that's the first box Sentinels ticks. Secondly, I love the card game, which I also own, so being able to play more often, and with friends abroad, ticks the second box. Thirdly, the game works well and has a nice, clean style that clings nearly perfectly to the card game (with some eye candy added), which is the third box. Fourth point, the game clarifies some rules interactions I hadn't thought of, so that's box number four. Not having to do all the number-crunching yourself is a fifth plus. The only downsides to the Steam version are that you can't enjoy holding the cards in your hand, that buying multiple copies for friends after you've bought a single game for yourself doesn't seem to work (the gift button remains grayed out), and that my favourite character hasn't been published yet and doesn't seem to be in the chute for publication either.\n\nOh, and I also like the music. I wouldn't say it's anything special, but it's catchy and fits the game very well.

The card art is extremely rough around the edges and could probably do with an update someday, but hot damn the mechanics and general feel of the game are well crafted. Honestly the art doesn't detract a lot from the experience and it is all a certain unified comic book style rather than differing per deck, so it's neat how it all ties together.

It's a little plodding in pacing sometimes, and some card actions require a bit of streamlining (you to tell the system to go ahead with a default more than not, in my experience), but generally the game is actually really good fun, The team versus villain thing works well, as it makes the game cooperative with friends (so there's no Mario Party situation of everyone falling out), and having the environment as a deck with its own turn makes things interesting to work with, since you have to keep reacting to both the villain and a general hazard in the background.

The gameplay is pretty solid aside from the minor hiccups mentioned earlier though - there's decks that work well together such as Visionary and Haka, where Visionary causes Haka to draw loads of cards and Haka consumes them all in his power up moves, and Absolute Zero works beautifully on his own to back up most any roster of teams. Villains will often require you to act a certain way to counter them, or generally favour a certain type of team, but it's pretty fun to learn these and beat them once you've figured out the patterns.

I'd give it a decent 8/10!
